prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We observe the spectral lines simultaneously with high velocity resolution together with continuum emission. Although our target line is the [CI] line, we also include the CS(10-9) line for additional information. We use two basebands for the lines and the other for the Band8 continuum emission.
To reduce the data rate, we employ 58 MHz bandwidth backend configuration for the lines and the 16 ch spectral averaging is applied, providing 0.15 km/s velocity resolution. We will smooth the velocity resolution to 0.4 km/s through the data analysis to achieve better sensitivity, which is still significant to resolve the velocity structure of the disk. For the continuum emission, we employ center frequencies of 479.5 and 477.6 GHz, where the sky condition is relatively good.

In the proposed observation, we don't aim to resolving the disk structure in detail, but at detecting the [CI] emission and estimating the total flux density of that. Therefore, a moderate resolution of 1.0 arcsec is required. Assuming that the size of the [CI] emission is similar to that of the CO disk, the disk radius is ~6 arcsec as listed in Table 1 of SJ. With the required resolution, the disk structure can be moderately resolved. The requested largest angular scale is reasonable if the velocity structure of the disk is well resolved.

The required sensitivity is estimated on the basis of our previous works by using the ASTE. The desired sensitivity is calculated for our target line, the [CI] emission line. The peak intensity of the [CI] emission obtained with the ASTE was 0.17 K in the TA scale. After the correction of the beam dilution effect by assuming that the size of the [CI] emission is identical to that of the CO emission, the brightness temperature is expected to be 0.83 K. Assuming that the emission uniformly distributes over the disk, we can detect the [CI] emission at least 5sigma with a sensitivity of 0.16 K, corresponding to 33 mJy per 1.0" synthesized beam at 492 GHz. For the sensitivity calculation, we employ a velocity resolution of 0.4 km/s, which is enough to resolve the velocity structure of the disk.
In this case, the continuum sensitivity obtained by the aggregated bandwidth becomes 423.3 uJy. Assuming the spectral index at submillimeter is 2, which means the power-law index of the dust mass opacity coefficient is 0, the flux density of the continuum emission at 492 GHz is estimated to be 500 mJy from that at 230 GHz. Therefore, the continuum sensitivity is sufficient to detect even if the emission is resolved.

We observe the spectral lines simultaneously with high velocity resolution together with continuum emission. Although our target line is the [CI] line, we also include the CS(10-9) line for additional information. We use two basebands for the lines and the other for the Band8 continuum emission.
To reduce the data rate, we employ 58 MHz bandwidth backend configuration for the lines and the 16 ch spectral averaging is applied, providing 0.15 km/s velocity resolution. We will smooth the velocity resolution to 0.4 km/s through the data analysis to achieve better sensitivity, which is still significant to resolve the velocity structure of the disk. For the continuum emission, we employ center frequencies of 479.5 and 477.6 GHz, where the sky condition is relatively good.

In the proposed observation, we don't aim to resolving the disk structure in detail, but at detecting the [CI] emission and estimating the total flux density of that. Therefore, a moderate resolution of 1.0 arcsec is required. Assuming that the size of the [CI] emission is similar to that of the CO disk, the disk radius is ~4 arcsec as listed in Table 1 of SJ. With the required resolution, the disk structure can be moderately resolved. The requested largest angular scale is reasonable if the velocity structure of the disk is well resolved.

The expected intensity of the [CI] emission is estimated by assuming that the brightness temperature is the same as that of DM Tau. After the correction of the distance to the source, the expected peak flux density is 1.03 Jy, and therefore we can detect the [CI] emission above 5sigma with a sensitivity of 206 mJy. For the sensitivity calculation, we employ a velocity resolution of 0.4 km/s, which is enough to resolve the velocity structure of the disk.
In the same was as for DM Tau, the expected flux density of the continuum emission is estimated to be 2.6 Jy. Therefore, the sufficient SN is achieved with a continuum sensitivity of 817 uJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to observe protoplanetary disks around T Tauri and Herbig AeBe stars in the [CI] 3P1-3P0 line at 1" resolution. Atomic carbon is a unique probe for understanding disk dissipation and dust evolution in the disk, but a fine-structure line of atomic carbon at submillimeter wavelengths was not detected from a protoplanetary disk until very recently. However, we recently reported the first detection of [CI] emission from the protoplanetary disk around a low-mass T Tauri star with the Band8QM receiver mounted on the ASTE telescope. The next step to be taken is a survey of a representative sample of the disks to increase the number of detection.
Our targets are nine well-studied disks in nearby star forming regions. If the [CI] emission is successfully detected from these targets, we will get clues for understanding the nature of atomic carbon in protoplanetary disks. These observations will provide us new information about the physical/chemical conditions in the upper layer of the disk. Our sample covers wide ranges of spectral type and age, and thus we will be able to discuss the connection between the [CI] emitting condition and the stellar properties.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: The Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency
ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Nobeyama Radio Observatory, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
